title: Lucy Mecklenburgh reveals hate she got for working out while pregnant
text:
‘One women told me that her midwife said exercise would kill her baby’ (Picture: Getty)

Becoming pregnant can open you up to a whole world of unwelcome opinions.

Suddenly everyone knows what you should be eating, what you should be wearing, how you should be sleeping – and they will insist on telling you their opinions. But no one asked you, Karen.

When you’re pregnant, every single thing you do comes under scrutiny and your every action takes on a new, moral significance. From choosing to have a glass of wine to carrying your own shopping bags home.

TV personality Lucy Mecklenburgh knows how hard it can be to deal with this level of judgement after facing a barrage of online criticism for posting workout videos online while pregnant.

She says that while a lot of women have been supportive of her for promoting an active pre-natal lifestyle, other comments have left her really upset.

‘Remarks questioning why I exercise during my pregnancy have cropped up,’ explains the former TOWIE star.

‘These have included statements such as, “working out is selfish, think of the baby before yourself”, or even more radically, one women told me that her midwife said exercise would kill her baby, and questioned if I was worried about this.’

Lucy has her own fitness app Results with Lucy, which features thousands of workouts and live classes as well as nutritional and mindset training – so working out is literally part of her job.

Now she wants to raise awareness about the taboo of working out while pregnant and help promote the health benefits of staying physically active when you’re expecting.

‘The comments I’ve had have driven me to help remove the stigma that exercise during pregnancy is dangerous – it is beneficial for both mother and child. I think it’s a matter of educating women about this topic.

‘There are, of course, exceptions when pregnant mothers should avoid exercise: if you have been told by a medical professional that you cannot workout or if you’re experiencing hyperemesis gravidarum (severe morning sickness).

‘However, if this is not the case, there is no reason why mothers shouldn’t be encouraged to be active.’

Recent research actually found that vigorous exercise is ‘safe and healthy’ for women in their third trimester – that includes jogging, circuits, or interval training on a spin bike.

The benefits of keeping fit during pregnancy Exercise prepares the body for postural changes by strengthening muscles that may become weak; both abdominal and pelvic floor muscles are strengthened to support labour and post-natal recovery. In general, keeping active helps to maintain, or even improve, muscular strength and endurance to support the demands of pregnancy, labour and being a mum (car seats are very heavy). Other examples include the fact that it reduces backache, increases your vitality, improves your ability to dissipate heat and reduces the risk of pre-eclampsia (high-blood pressure during pregnancy). Lucy Mecklenburgh

‘Personally, I found it incredibly hard when I couldn’t work out during my first trimester,’ Lucy tells us. ‘This was due to severe morning sickness and tiredness.

‘The toughest challenges that I had to overcome was the sense of losing my identity and the lack of endorphins, which are mood boosters. Needless to say – I really missed keeping fit.

‘However, I managed to start exercising again around the 12-13-week mark.’

Lucy believes it’s sensible to be cautious about exercising when you’re pregnant.

Doctors have now been reiterating for years that exercise is not dangerous for your baby and that cardiovascular exercise can be really beneficial. But everyone is different, and every pregnancy is different – so it’s worth seeking out personal advice before getting struck in.

‘I encourage research prior to prenatal workouts,’ says Lucy. ‘The blogs and vlogs on my fitness website provide expert advice concerning pregnancy workouts, nutrition and mental health.

‘Pre- and postnatal workouts are also included, which feature barre, Pilates, yoga, weights and boxing.’

It’s important to remember that your body is your business, and carrying another human life inside you doesn’t grant anyone the privilege of telling you what to do.

Sensible, doctor-approved exercise is fantastic for pregnant women – so if you’re facing judgement for having the audacity to jump on a treadmill while with-child, feel free to ignore the haters.
